channel.title: Posts on Rajath Ramakrishna
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Rajath Ramakrishna

item.title: Ideas Need Sufficient Baketime
item.description: I’ve always been curious about learning new things. I’ve always consumed new information with great enthusiasm. I’d read book after book, blog post after blog post and listen to lot of podcasts and audiobooks.

item.title: Exporting Google Photos
item.description: I recently purchased a Synology NAS and I started hosting a media server containing movies, TV shows and photos. I had stored all my photos in Google Photos for the past several years.

item.title: 2020 - Year in Review
item.description: 2020 has been quite a year for all of us and I don’t want to get into the long list of things that have shook us this year.

item.title: OrgMode Smart Archive
item.description: So far, my workflow in OrgMode for managing tasks and events was to have one file called organize.org that contains top-level headings - Tasks, Events that contained respective items.

item.title: My Hugo Setup Part 3
item.description: This is the third installment of my Hugo Setup. In this post I explain how I added support for “series” in my blog and also provide links that can be used for further explorations.

item.title: My Hugo Setup Part 2
item.description: In my previous post, I explained all the visual tweaks I did to my Hugo blog theme so that I could get the pages I wanted in the format I liked the most.

item.title: My Hugo Setup
item.description: I recently moved my blog to Hugo and wrote a brief post about it. This post explains how I selected a theme and how I made the modifications I needed.

item.title: Moving to Hugo
item.description: I’ve used Jekyll as a static site generator ever since I created this blog, which was in 2013. Before that, I had tried few other blogging platforms.

item.title: 2019 in Review
item.description: Another year done, and like always time flies by quicker and quicker every year. 2019 has been quite eventful in a few aspects and I took some time to reflect on how things went.

item.title: 2018 in Review
item.description: 2018 went by really quick. It was one of the more eventful years - packed with activities, travel, new hobbies, experiences and accomplishments.

item.title: The Dreaded 65k Method Limit on Android
item.description: If you’re an Android developer, it’s likely that you have experienced this at least a few times during your development.

item.title: Two Months With Project Fi
item.description: It’s been 2 months since I started using Project Fi on my Nexus 6P and I thought I’ll write my review about it.

item.title: Book Review: Alchemist
item.description: Alchemist by Paulo Coelho is the first book I read in 2016. This book had been in my to-read list for quite a while now and I thought I’ll give it a read.

item.title: 2015 - Lessons Learned
item.description: I saw a couple of posts about what people did in 2015 (this and this) that inspired me to write my own.

item.title: Macbook users must swap Caps Lock and Ctrl Keys. Seriously!
item.description: I tell this to everyone I meet who uses a MacBook. I mean, come on. People who are used to using a Windows keyboard put their pinky on the bottom left key of the keyboard to reach for the control key, and it’s easy to reach too since the Ctrl key is pretty wide.

item.title: Taskr - the simplest task management app
item.description: I started off 2015 by making an Android app. I created a very simple todo list app called Taskr. This was mainly to brush up my Android skills and get my hands dirty while digging into Material Design.

item.title: Graduated :)
item.description: Today I graduated with Masters in Computer Science from University of Illinois at Chicago. It’s been about two years since I came to this country and I had some really nice experiences working with my project mates, doing my internship, attending meetups and hackathons, spending sleepless nights working on projects and assignments while surviving on pizza, and sometimes coffee.

item.title: Weekly Noise #16 - Wrap up and future enhancements
item.description: All in all, this project was an extremely interesting one. We got to learn a lot from this project, especially being new to Android development.

item.title: Weekly Noise #15 - Experimental Results
item.description: Two phones were used as part of testing – LG Nexus 4 and HTC One. Logging was done multiple times during the day, between 11am and 5pm.

item.title: Weekly Noise #14 - Navigation and Voice Alerts
item.description: This week we concentrated on Navigation and Voice Alerts. Calculation of the route path is quite easy and it’s a one-time task, the results of which will be used repetitively for navigation.

item.title: Weekly Noise #13 - Routing Algorithm
item.description: This week we implemented the Routing Algorithm. We considered each intersection as a checkpoint and made a graph out of the navigation paths and the corresponding intersection points among them.

item.title: Weekly Noise #12 - Geofencing
item.description: Geofencing is a concept wherein a fence is created around a particular area and any action can be performed once a mobile device enters this fence.

item.title: Weekly Noise #11 - Online Phase
item.description: The online phase is where scans are made periodically and matched with the offline database to find the current location of the user.

item.title: Weekly Noise #10 - Offline Phase Complete
item.description: In order to bulk load the parking cell data, I chose to use a JSON file as it is simpler to edit cell information (if need be).

item.title: Weekly Noise #9 - Managing Database
item.description: After last week’s development, there was pretty good progress with the project. We managed to get the following things done:

item.title: Weekly Noise #8 - Database Schema
item.description: As per the design, we created database schemas, tables and other relevant classes: Database: parking_table to store information about the parking slots.

item.title: Weekly Noise #7 - My Development Environment
item.description: Before I go to the details about the working of the project, I would like to explain my Development Environment - the tools I use and why I use them.

item.title: Weekly Noise #6 - Design
item.description: ParkAssist In my previous post I gave a brief overview about the project that I was working on and its problem statement.

item.title: Weekly Noise #5 - My Masters Project
item.description: I would like to give a glimpse of what my Masters Project is all about and what I will be working on in the next couple of months.

item.title: Weekly Noise #4 - Hibernation
item.description: It’s been quite a while since I last updated my blog. I was busy with exams and then vacations. I went back home (Bangalore, India) after about 1.

item.title: Weekly Noise #3 - New Domain
item.description: As promised, last week I integrated Medium-style “time-to-read” kind of feature which is pretty much added manually since Jekyll is a static blog generator.

item.title: Weekly Noise #2 - Theme Enhancements
item.description: Last week I worked on the theme to modify few things which I have explained in the My Theme Setup post.

item.title: My Theme Setup
item.description: First of all, kudos to @mmistakes for coming up with such an elegant theme called So Simple. Everything looks perfect and every component is placed where it’s supposed to be.

item.title: Weekly Noise #1 - Moving to GitHub Pages
item.description: To set the context, Weekly Noise series is where I talk about what I accomplished during the week (like working on my personal projects among other things) and also set the goals for next week.

item.title: Hello World
item.description: After being lazy as a sloth for a “really long” time, I finally pushed myself to create a blog where I can write/share about projects I work on in my free time and also about the technologies/tools that I encounter every now and then.
